ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Basic statistical knowledge, coding in R, a lot of helpful small logical things for a QR credit

Great intro to R!! I had never coded in my life so we learned beginner R code along with using it in combination with other packages and add ons to simplify things. Overall learned how to explore data, create visualizations for it, and perform statistical analysis as learned in s&ds 101.

I gained a foundation understanding of statistics, learned about statistical distributions and probability, learned about analytical techniques like linear regression, and gained a basic understanding of coding in R and RStudio.
Basis of statistics and applying them in r. I would highly recommend 106 to the other 100-s because of the R-Studio part. It makes stats so much more fun.
using R and analyzing datasets with R
I was able to learn a great deal about Statistics, particularly through the programming language of R.

Umbrella course: Basics of statistics and how to use minitab. Descriptive statistics (mean, median, mode, IQR, range), probability, conditional probability. How experiments and results should be conducted and analyzed, respectively, from a statistics standpoint.

106: Basics of R.
How to use R
How to code in R

S&DS 10X (first half of sem) I learned basic, essential stats.
S&DS 106 (second half of sem) I learned basic, essential R coding.
Introductory knowledge to statistics and R-coding.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: potential to be asynchronous for the first 8 weeks which was very helpful for me and all the tests are online and 106 has a final project instead of a test
Weaknesses: being online, I did not learn as much as I could have maybe if I went in person
Strengths: professor is easy to understand and helpful, content is taught in an intuitive manner and sequence that makes sense, practical

Strengths: first half of the course was at your own pace, the workload of the class never felt too much, the second half of the course was also very relevant to my studies. Weaknesses: clearer rubrics and grading scales might have been helpful.

Strengths: R was cool to learn.  A great way to start programming.
Weaknesses: Fast-paced
I really enjoyed the second half of the class where we learned R as it was very well geared to beginners and I felt I learned a lot in the 4 weeks we had it
strengths: very accessible for first-time coders like me, the pace was a really good balance of accessible but still quick-paced.
The strength is that it is engaging, and the weaknesses are that it feels unorganized and is arduous at times. It can be improved by having more office hour opportunities.

Umbrella:
Strengths:
Weaknesses:

106:
Strengths: Students were appropriately pushed given the assumed background of no experience with R. So the homework wasn't overly difficult, but also not super easy either. 
Weaknesses: The time is just so short that you don't really get to learn anything and the connection to statistics is very weak, so I'm not really sure why they're combined this way. Students are given some resources to learn R during the umbrella class, but at that point you're essentially teaching yourself so why take the class? No separate rubric for grade weighting was provided, so assuming the umbrella course is applicable, the final project is weighted especially heavily given the limited abilities of students.
The independence

I wish 106 was recorded and posted online because I was sick for a couple days and because the course is so short missing two classes makes a difference. Also, it would be helpful to have the class on Zoom anyways with the prof's screen shared on Zoom, even for those in the class, because then we can follow along on our own computer screens which is easier to see and keep up with. We did this for only the first class (because of technical difficulties with the projector) and it was a bit disappointing that we did not continue the rest of the class in the same manner.

Strengths: Both halves of the course are very well structured and I learned a lot from both JDRS and Wooster. JDRS's office hours were super helpful for Psets and general understanding and he was a nice, knowledgable, welcoming teacher. I think the asynchronous nature of S&DS 10X is a strength, but you just need to be careful to stay motivated so you do not fall behind on the lectures. Overall I appreciated the asynchronous nature of S&DS 10X. On the other hand, Wooster's S&DS 106 class was only in-person; Wooster has an engaging, hands-on lecture style and I definitely felt that my engagement increased in the second half simply due to being forced to go to class every week. I think asynch worked for S&DS 10X and in-person worked for S&DS 106. Also, the large selection of office hours were helpful for the course.  

Weaknesses: I wish we had more time to learn about the coding / 106 stuff. We learned a lot for the time we had, but five weeks is not that much time.

The option for asynchronous format was both a strength and a weakness as it gave the flexibility to choose our own schedules as long as we didn't fall behind. Better communication with professor would be beneficial- it sometimes took weeks to receive a reply.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes for an easy QR credit especially if you have taken AP stats in high school. I did not and still found it very manageable. I really enjoyed learning how to code in the last 5 weeks with professor Wooster, but also could have been since I went in person.
Yes! Great intro to R course, I had never coded before and had minimal stats experience but felt it was doable to stay on track and the TA's and professor are helpful. I think I learned a lot.

I would highly recommend this course to other students, particularly first years. I think this course provides a foundation in statistics and coding in R that comes up often in other classes or other papers. The skills are highly applicable to jobs and internships as well.
Yes. I think it's a great intro to Statistics class.
Yes. Especially the second half as it was a very good intro course and super helpful in learning R basics
Yes, I think it's so much more powerful to know a little bit of R than sticking to matlab for statistics.
Yes I would, as this was a great deal of learning in one class.

Umbrella course: Yes, it teaches important concepts about statistics that help with understanding not only within the STEM world, but across all fields.
S&DS 106: Not really. If you want to learn R, you should probably sign up for another class that teaches it separately since you don't really learn a lot. The statistics application within R is also very limited given students' lack of knowledge. Overall not really worth the chaos of switching.
if you have to take a QR or stats for your major, this is a great course.
Yes, it was great
Yes, for learning R
Yes! If you want to / have to learn intro stats, JDRS and Wooster are great teachers and the class as a whole is solid.
I definitely would recommend this course to a student who would like some introductory knowledge into statistics or a non-stem major trying to fulfill their QR credit!
